issue.title: What is the relationship between `AmbientColor::brightness`, Filament's IBL intensity, and Blender's background color strength?

labels.name: C-Docs
labels.description: An addition or correction to our documentation

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: S-Needs-Investigation
labels.description: This issue requires detective work to figure out what's going wrong

labels.name: D-Modest
labels.description: A "normal" level of difficulty; suitable for simple features or challenging fixes

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## How can Bevy's documentation be improved?

During Bevy 0.13's development, lots of attention went to `PointLight`, `DirectionalLight` and `Spotlight`. However, I failed to find any significant discussion of `AmbientLight` either on GitHub nor Discord. I'd be glad to be proved wrong if anyone's got a link though :)

The reason I care about this because the general consensus has been "let's try to have some kind of conformance with Blender", using Blender's EV100 and render outputs as direct references for how Bevy should behave. This worked out (mostly, there's still talk about Blender itself being wrong in places) for the lights mentioned, but `AmbientLight` kind of got left behind.

In Blender, under the tab "World", you can find the background light (aka environment light). The meaning behind its `strength` param is a bit elusive to me, and [the docs are not helping](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/render/shader_nodes/shader/background.html).

This is how Blender renders a scene with no lights and only a background light of strength 1:

![image](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/9047632/00ca90de-016f-4ff7-8fbe-3b2f04d03fb0)

This is how Bevy renders the same scene with no lights and an `AmbientLight` of the same color with brightness 1:
![image](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/9047632/eb0830e1-826d-44e1-bf66-745be6549c70)

As you can see, Bevy is *much* darker. (Ignore the procedural sky and the glowing orb, I just modified Foxtrot for the screenshots because it was handy)

Let's bump the brightness to the [slightly magic constant 683](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AKhronosGroup%2FglTF-Blender-IO%20PBR_WATTS_TO_LUMENS%20&type=code):
![image](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/assets/9047632/3687820d-de71-461c-87a4-a1ad8b76acb5)

Better, but very blue.


https://github.com/google/filament/issues/1667 says that using Blender's exposure settings (which are Bevy's standard settings), the background strength should be the same as their IBL intensity, which I believe corresponds to Bevy's [`EnvironmentMapLight::intensity`](https://docs.rs/bevy/latest/bevy/pbr/prelude/struct.EnvironmentMapLight.html#structfield.intensity). I would love to test this, but I fail to create a valid environment map from a simple `Color` using `Image::new` since I keep getting an error like "Texture binding 13 expects dimension = Cube, but given a view with dimension = D(1, 2 or 3)" no matter what I do. I am not an expert in the `Image` API, so this is probably possible in some way.

Until someone confirms or denies this, my working hypothesis is that Blender's background shader strength corresponds to the intensity of an environment map with a single color.

body:
`brightness` is a multiplier, so it itself does not have any units. It was originally added in #1605, where it calculates:

```rust
(ambient_light_resource.color * ambient_light_resource.brightness)
```

Which is equivalent to a `Vec4 * f32`. On main, it currently looks like:

https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/blob/a9ca8491aa3f2dc99116e63d67a0625afe6e738d/crates/bevy_pbr/src/render/light.rs#L983-L984

You could say the same thing about the skybox's [`brightness`](https://docs.rs/bevy/0.13.0/bevy/core_pipeline/struct.Skybox.html#structfield.brightness) field. The documentation I'm looking for is the analog of this line:

> Scale factor applied to the skybox image. After applying this multiplier to the image samples, the resulting values should be in units of [cd/m^2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candela_per_square_metre).
That's a very good point. So would `AmbientLight::brightness` also be in cd/m^2, or would it be some other unit?
Looking at the code I think @fintelia ’s last comment is the correct answer.

Marking this as a good first issue. [`AmbientLight`](https://dev-docs.bevyengine.org/bevy/pbr/struct.AmbientLight.html)'s brightness field should document that it is in [cd/m^2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candela_per_square_metre), similar to [`Skybox::brightness`](https://dev-docs.bevyengine.org/bevy/core_pipeline/struct.Skybox.html#structfield.brightness), if I'm understanding @superdump's comment correctly.

Maybe it would also be good to specify that this is *not* equivalent to Filament's [IBL](https://google.github.io/filament/Filament.md.html#lighting/imagebasedlights/iblunit), even though the units are the same and they are both used for global illumination.

@janhohenheim my understanding is that if one sets bevy’s ambient light brightness to 1 then it would be the same. Or you can consider the combination of color * brightness to be the same as Filament’s IBL.

@superdump I'm very skeptical because per https://github.com/google/filament/issues/1667, Blender's background shader is the same as IBL, but my testing in https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/12280 reveals that it does not correspond at all to an `AmbientLight` when using a strength of 1.
Of course, I might be wrong in how I export stuff from Blender, so take this with a grain of salt.

issue.title: Specify units in `AmbientLight::brightness` docs

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

- Fixes #11933.
- Related: #12280.

## Solution

- Specify that, after applying `AmbientLight`, the resulting units are in cd/m^2.
- This is based on [@fintelia's comment](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/issues/11933#issuecomment-1995427587), and will need to be verified.

---

## Changelog

- Specified units for `AmbientLight`'s `brightness` field.
